title: 103_s2336
content: The "Federal Communications Commission Authorization Act of 1994" authorizes appropriations for the administration of the Communications Act of 1934 by the Commission. The Act also includes provisions for travel reimbursement authority. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to update travel reimbursement authority, communications support for older Americans, the Hawaii monitoring station, and inspection of ship radio stations. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow contracting out inspections and require annual inspections for vessels. The Commission may designate an entity for inspections, and vessels can waive the annual inspection for up to 90 days to complete their voyage. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow contracting out inspections for vessels. Vessels can waive the annual inspection if in compliance with the Safety Convention and operating solely in waters beyond the US jurisdiction. Inspections must be done within 30 days of the vessel's return to the US. Additionally, the Act is amended to allow the Commission to designate an entity for inspections. SEC. 7. EXPEDITED ITFS PROCESSING. Amends the Communications Act of 1934 regarding the authorization of service in the Instructional Television Fixed Service. SEC. 8. APPLICATION FEES. Modification of Fees in the Communications Act of 1934 involves adjusting application fees annually to meet specified total collections, with the Commission having the authority to round fees to the nearest $5. The Commission has the authority to adjust application fees annually and round them to the nearest $5 or $20. They can also collect fees at the prior year's rate until modifications take effect. Additionally, the Commission can add, delete, or reclassify services subject to fees based on rulemaking proceedings or changes in law. The Commission has the authority to adjust application fees annually and round them to the nearest $5 or $20. They can also collect fees at the prior year's rate until modifications take effect. The action taken under paragraph (4) involves determining the full-time equivalent number of employees performing application activities, adjusting for related expenses, and notifying Congress of any proposed fee modifications or amendments. $40,000,000 of the fees received will be deposited in the general fund. The Commission has the authority to adjust application fees annually and round them to the nearest $5 or $20. They can also collect fees at the prior year's rate until modifications take effect. $40,000,000 of the fees received will be deposited in the general fund of the Treasury to reimburse the United States, with the remainder credited to the account providing appropriations for the Commission's functions. Amendments are made to Section 6(d) of the Act regarding appropriated funds. The Schedule of Application Fees for Personal Communications Services is amended to include various fees for different applications. This includes fees for initial applications, amendments, transfers of control, license renewals, special temporary authority requests, construction completion notifications, and service area combinations. The Communications Act of 1934 is being amended to allow the Commission to assess and collect regulatory fees to cover executive and legal costs. Additionally, adjustments and amendments must now be notified to Congress within 30 days instead of 90 days. The Commission can continue to collect fees at the prior year's rate until new rates take effect. The Commission can collect fees at the prior year's rate until any adjustment or amendment of that fee under this section. SEC. 11 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a detailed report on fee modifications, including reasons for changes and anticipated adjustments. SEC. 12 grants tariff rejection authority. SEC. 12 grants the Commission the authority to reject proposed tariffs if they are deemed patently unlawful after inviting comments from interested parties. The Commission may consider additional information and presume the carrier's allegations to be true. SEC. 13 amends the Communications Act of 1934 to allow the Commission to order carriers to refund charges resulting from violations of the Act. The refund, with interest, must be paid to the affected party within 5 years of the charge being paid. SEC. 14 amends the Communications Act of 1934 to license aviation, maritime, and personal radio services by rule. It specifies the radio services for aircraft and ship stations operated on domestic voyages. SEC. 15. AUCTION TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. Section 309(j)(8) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow offsetting collections to remain available until expended. The FCC is authorized to deposit bid monies in an interest-bearing account until accepting a deposit from the high bidder, with interest earned going to the Treasury. The bid monies deposited from unsuccessful bidders will be returned to them, minus any fees and penalties. SEC. 16. FORFEITURE FOR ACT OR RULE VIOLATIONS IMPERILING SAFETY OF LIFE. Administrative Sanctions and Forfeitures amended to include penalties for failure to comply with Act or Commission's rules endangering safety of life. The Commission's rules amended to include penalties for endangering safety of life. SEC. 17. Amends the Communications Act of 1934 regarding the statute of limitations for forfeiture proceedings against common carriers.
